provenanceData.sentence: Nancy Capelle's decision to call for an ambulance was the key for why she's alive today to tell her story, but not many people know how Wilton's emergency medical services operate and what happens when they call 9-1-1.
Thankfully, had a happy ending—the paramedic and EMTs who responded to her call were instrumental in saving her life after she suffered a heart attack at home.
Thankfully, had a happy ending—the paramedic and EMTs who responded to her call were instrumental in saving her life after she suffered a heart attack at home.
"Call volume is up almost 20 percent this year, I don't know why.

"Once we arrive on scene, and assess what the situation is, if the patient has to go to the hospital and the need is advanced life support, which is a very serious thing, then the paramedic has to go along.

"Once we arrive on scene, and assess what the situation is, if the patient has to go to the hospital and the need is advanced life support, which is a very serious thing, then the paramedic has to go along.

"Once we arrive on scene, and assess what the situation is, if the patient has to go to the hospital and the need is advanced life support, which is a very serious thing, then the paramedic has to go along.
EMTs in Wilton are volunteers, they have other things that they do, either they are working elsewhere or are retired."

We actually rely heavily on that because [through fundraising] the corps pays for things like training, uniforms, we actually buy the paramedic vehicle," said Hitter.

Depending on the nature and seriousness of the call, Hitter said the fire department will also be dispatched because they are first responders as well.
Depending on the nature and seriousness of the call, Hitter said the fire department will also be dispatched because they are first responders as well.

Ron Hitter, the president of the Wilton Volunteer Ambulance Corps (WVAC) explains that, surprisingly, a good portion of emergency medical services available to the town residents isn't even funded by the town.

If it's basic life support, then just the EMTs can handle the call and they'll transport the patient to the hospital."

Nancy Capelle's decision to call for an ambulance was the key for why she's alive today to tell her story, but not many people know how Wilton's emergency medical services operate and what happens when they call 9-1-1.

Nancy Capelle's decision to call for an ambulance was the key for why she's alive today to tell her story, but not many people know how Wilton's emergency medical services operate and what happens when they call 9-1-1.
When You Call 911 in Wilton, Here's What Happens
When You Call 911 in Wilton, Here's What Happens
When You Call 911 in Wilton, Here's What Happens

Because of the association with Weston and Norwalk, Hitter explained that they operate on a system of mutual aid: when the Wilton-based medic is called to Weston, Norwalk will send another paramedic to Wilton as a backup; if Norwalk needs help, Wilton can send their EMTs to support them as well.

Because of the association with Weston and Norwalk, Hitter explained that they operate on a system of mutual aid: when the Wilton-based medic is called to Weston, Norwalk will send another paramedic to Wilton as a backup; if Norwalk needs help, Wilton can send their EMTs to support them as well.

Because of the association with Weston and Norwalk, Hitter explained that they operate on a system of mutual aid: when the Wilton-based medic is called to Weston, Norwalk will send another paramedic to Wilton as a backup; if Norwalk needs help, Wilton can send their EMTs to support them as well.

According to Hitter, the first responder to a 9-1-1 call is always a Wilton police officer; because cruisers are spread throughout the vast area of the town at any given moment, police officers will likely be able to arrive to an emergency first.

The corps is staffed by approximately 45 volunteer EMTs and—through a partnership between Norwalk Hospital, the WVAC, and the towns of Wilton and Weston—there is always a paramedic on staff 24/7.
provenanceData.text: The corps is staffed by approximately 45 volunteer EMTs and—through a partnership between Norwalk Hospital , the WVAC , and the towns of Wilton and Weston—there is always a paramedic on staff 24/7 .

provenanceData.sentence: While the paramedics are technically employees of Norwalk Hospital, WVAC contracts with the hospital to have the paramedics work full-time out of their headquarters behind the Wilton police department, "24 hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year," Hitter said.
provenanceData.text: While the paramedics are technically employees of Norwalk Hospital , WVAC contracts with the hospital to have the paramedics work full-time out of their headquarters behind the Wilton police department , " 24 hours a day , seven days a week , 365 days a year ," Hitter said .

Because of the association with Weston and Norwalk, Hitter explained that they operate on a system of mutual aid: when the Wilton-based medic is called to Weston, Norwalk will send another paramedic to Wilton as a backup; if Norwalk needs help, Wilton can send their EMTs to support them as well.

provenanceData.sentence: Because of the association with Weston and Norwalk, Hitter explained that they operate on a system of mutual aid: when the Wilton-based medic is called to Weston, Norwalk will send another paramedic to Wilton as a backup; if Norwalk needs help, Wilton can send their EMTs to support them as well.

Because of the association with Weston and Norwalk, Hitter explained that they operate on a system of mutual aid: when the Wilton-based medic is called to Weston, Norwalk will send another paramedic to Wilton as a backup; if Norwalk needs help, Wilton can send their EMTs to support them as well.

While the paramedics are technically employees of Norwalk Hospital, WVAC contracts with the hospital to have the paramedics work full-time out of their headquarters behind the Wilton police department, "24 hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year," Hitter said.
